bibl.title: Letter from John R. and Ida E. Kissinger to Howard A. Kelly, May 24, 1908

div1.p: The Kissingers inform Kelly that they have moved to a less expensive house. John Kissinger's health continues to worsen.

div1.head: Letter from John R. and Ida E. Kissinger to Howard A. Kelly, May 24, 1908
div1.opener:
May 24/08
Howard A Kelly.
Dear Kind and
helpful friend
div1.p:
your letter to hand
and I returned a card to you
we have been moving into a
Place where we get cheaper Rent
10 dollars a month. We save 2 a
month by so doing and every cent
saved is one earned to us.
Mr Kissinger felt quite discouraged
as we only had that to build hopes
on its such hard time here
people who we did work for on
dropping out untill it seems
we will hardly be able to live
2
every one feels' they must save for
themselves some of the largest
manofactures are only Runing on
5 hours, and of course usually
its those places that keeps things
working

I have worked untill at times I get
so tired and discouraged that
it seems to me I must give
up. I was sick which cost us so
much for Dr bill and we paid
it one thing we have kept out
of Dept we dont owe a person a
cent we know of. Can say that
you have been our only true and
helpful friend that is through
your influence

Sometimes I say that I give
up I am so out of clothing
and everything to make me appear
respectable I am ashamed I
could check once in a while
but for my clothes I cant do it
3
its been beyond my thoughts to
ask for help out I am finding
I may have to do so. We have
certainly tried to help ourselves
we thank you so much for your
Kindness Mr Kissinger sends
Kindest Regards to you he isnt
as stout, he seems to get weaker
could you advise us at all
div1.closer:
your true friends Mrs and Mr Kissinger 810 Milton Ave
South Bend
Ind.
